facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 198 to 200 of 1959 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 198 to 200 of 1959. Appeals from the judgment and order dated the 5th March 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, in Writ Petitions Nos. 1511 and 1512 of 1958 and 23 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated 5th March 1959 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 1511 and 1512 of 1958 and 23 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated the 5th March 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court, in Writ Petitions Nos. 1511 and 1512 of 1958 and 23 of 1959. C. Chatterjee, G. Suryanarayana, K. Mangach and T. V. Tatachari, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants were carrying on motor transport business for several years in Krishna District in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were carrying on motor transport business for several years in Krishna District in the State of Andhra Pradesh. Shri Guru Pershad, styled as the General Manager of the State Transport Undertaking of the Andhra Pradesh Road Transport, published a scheme for nationalization of motor transport in the said State from the date to be notified by the State Government.

facts.text: Shri Guru Pershad, General Manager of the State Transport Undertaking, published a scheme for nationalization of motor transport.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Guru Pershad, styled as the General Manager of the State Transport Undertaking of the Andhra Pradesh Road Transport, published a scheme for nationalization of motor transport in the said State from the date to be notified by the State Government. Objections to the said proposed scheme were invited by the State Government, and the appellants, among others, filed their objections.

facts.text: Objections to the proposed scheme were filed by appellants among others.

anchor.surface_text: Objections to the said proposed scheme were invited by the State Government, and the appellants, among others, filed their objections. On December 26, 1957, the Secretary in charge of the Transport Department gave a personal hearing to the objectors and heard the representations made on behalf of the State Transport Undertaking.

facts.text: On December 26, 1957, Secretary in charge of Transport Department gave personal hearing to objectors.

anchor.surface_text: On December 26, 1957, the Secretary in charge of the Transport Department gave a personal hearing to the objectors and heard the representations made on behalf of the State Transport Undertaking. The entire material gathered by him was placed before the Chief Minister of the State in charge of transport who made the order approving the scheme.

facts.text: Chief Minister approved the scheme; published in Gazette on January 9, 1958, effective January 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The approved scheme was published in the Andhra Pradesh Gazette dated January 9, 1958, and it was directed to come into force with effect from January 10, 1958. Thereafter the Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation, which was formed under the provisions of the Road Transport Corporation Act, 1950, took over the Undertaking and proceeded to implement the scheme under a phased programme.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation formed under Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950, took over the undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation, which was formed under the provisions of the Road Transport Corporation Act, 1950, took over the Undertaking and proceeded to implement the scheme under a phased programme. The appellants moved this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution for quashing the said scheme on various grounds.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation delivered judgment on November 5, 1958, quashing the scheme approval.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are the off-shoot of the judgment of this Court in Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation 1 delivered on November 5, 1958. The facts were fully stated therein. It would be only necessary to recapitulate briefly the facts relevant to the present enquiry

facts.text: After SC order, Government issued notices for personal hearing by Chief Minister on December 9, 1958; objections by November 30, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: After the said order, notices were issued by the Government to all the objectors informing them that a personal hearing would be given by the Chief Minister on December 9, 1958, and they were further informed that they were at liberty to file further objections before November 30, 1958.

facts.text: Chief Minister passed orders dated December 19, 1958, approving the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister heard the representatives of the objectors and the Corporation and passed orders dated December 19, 1958, rejecting the objections filed and approving the scheme as originally published.

facts.text: Order approving scheme published in Gazette on December 22, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The order approving the scheme was duly published by the Government in the official Gazette on December 22, 1958. On December 23, 1958, the Corporation applied to the Road Transport Authority for the issue of permits for plying stage carriages and for eliminating the permits granted to the private bus operators.

facts.text: On December 23, 1958, Corporation applied to Regional Transport Authority for permits and cancelling private permits.

anchor.surface_text: On December 23, 1958, the Corporation applied to the Road Transport Authority for the issue of permits for plying stage carriages and for eliminating the permits granted to the private bus operators.

facts.text: On December 24, 1958, Regional Transport Authority cancelled appellants' permits effective December 24, 1958, issued to Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: On --December 24, 1958, the said Authority passed orders rendering the permits of the appellants ineffective from December 24, 1958, and also issuing permits to the Corporation in -respect of the routes previously operated by the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants directed to stop plying buses from December 25, 1958; orders communicated on December 24, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The said orders were communicated to the appellants on December 24, 1958, and they were also directed to stop plying their buses from December 25, 1958, on their respective routes.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions under Art. 226 in AP High Court against government and RTA orders; dismissed by Division Bench Chandra Reddy CJ and Srinivasachari J.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, who were aggrieved, by the orders of the Government as well by the order of the Regional Transport Authority filed petitions in the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the same. The petitions were heard by a Division Bench of the said High Court consisting of Chandra Reddy, C.J., and Srinivasachari, J., who negatived the contentions raised by the appellants and dismissed the petitions.

facts.text: Petitioners claimed Chief Minister was biased as he initiated scheme and made speeches showing prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: This Court held in Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation that the 1 1959 S.C.R. SUPPL. 319. Secretary in charge of the Transport Department was disqualified from deciding the dispute between the Department and the private bus operators on the basis of the principle that a party cannot be a judge in his own cause, and that, as the Chief Minister was in charge of the portfolio of transport, the same infirmity attached to him also,

facts.text: Respondents denied Chief Minister bias; stated he could hear as per statute, no personal bias proved.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate-General sought to make out a distinction between official bias of an authority which is inherent in a statutory duty imposed on it and personal bias of the said authority in favour of, or against, one of the parties and contended that the mere fact that the Chief Minister of the Government had supported the policy of nationalization, or even the fact that the Government initiated the said scheme, did not disqualify him from deciding the dispute unless it was established that he was guilty of personal bias,

facts.text: Newspaper reports of Chief Minister speeches on nationalization not proved by affidavits; Chief Minister did not admit.

anchor.surface_text: If it had been established that the Chief Minister made the speeches extracted in Exhibits VI, IX and X, there would have been considerable force in the argument of the learned Counsel for the appellants but no attempt was made to prove that the Chief Minister did in fact make those speeches.

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority did not give due notice before cancelling permits as per Rule 11.

anchor.surface_text: There are two defects in the procedure. followed by the Regional Transport Authority  i  while the rule enjoins on the Authority to issue notice to the persons affected before making the relevant order, the Authority made the order and communicated the same to the persons affected and  ii  while the rule requires due notice i.e., reasonable notice.,

facts.text: High Court dismissed writs despite RTA procedural defect, as no practical utility.

anchor.surface_text: But, in view of the supervening circumstances, the High Court, while noticing this defect in the procedure followed by the Regional Transport Authority, refused to exercise its jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on August 21, 1959 by Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. August 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-These appeals on certificates are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh, at Hyderabad, dismissing the petitions filed by the appellants under Art, 226 74 of the Constitution for issuing writs of certiorari to quash the orders of the Government of Andhra Pradesh confirming a scheme of nationalization of transport and the subsequent orders of the Regional Transport Authority cancelling the appellants stage carriage permits.

facts.text: Appellants held stage carriage permits cancelled by RTA.

anchor.surface_text: dismissing the petitions filed by the appellants under Art, 226 74 of the Constitution for issuing writs of certiorari to quash the orders of the Government of Andhra Pradesh confirming a scheme of nationalization of transport and the subsequent orders of the Regional Transport Authority cancelling the appellants stage carriage permits.

facts.text: Chief Minister heard objectors and Corporation representatives before approving scheme on Dec 19, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister heard the representatives of the objectors and the Corporation and passed orders dated December 19, 1958, rejecting the objections filed and approving the scheme as originally published. The order approving the scheme was duly published by the Government in the official Gazette on December 22, 1958.

facts.text: Appellants withdrew vehicles from routes after RTA order; Corporation vehicles plying since.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the order of the Regional Transport. Authority the appellants withdrew their vehicles from the concerned routes and the vehicles of the Road Transport Corporation have been plying on those routes.

under Art, 226 74 of the Constitution for issuing writs of certiorari to quash the orders of the Government of Andhra Pradesh confirming a scheme of nationalization of transport and the subsequent orders

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, who were aggrieved, by the orders of the Government as well by the order of the Regional Transport Authority filed petitions in the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the same.

But, in view of the supervening circumstances, the High Court, while noticing this defect in the procedure followed by the Regional Transport Authority, refused to exercise its jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether, when a statute confers a power on an authority and imposes a duty on it to be a judge of its own cause or to decide a dispute in which it has an official bias, the doctrine of bias is qualified to the extent of the statutory authorization

holdings.text: The doctrine of bias is not qualified to the extent of statutory authorization unless the legislature clearly and expressly provides otherwise.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows English precedents (King v. Bath Compensation Authority, King v. Leicester Justices) holding natural justice not derogated unless expressly stated; applies to Motor Vehicles Act which does not authorize government to judge own cause.

holdings.text: The provisions of the Act do not authorise the State Government to act in derogation of the principles of natural justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Act visualises State Government resolving conflict between Undertaking and private operators but does not permit bias or judging own cause.

holdings.text: The State Government did not act in violation of the principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the State Government, in the present case, acted in violation of the said principles. The argument that as this Court held in the previous stage of this litigation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects estoppel argument; distinguishes Secretary (part of department) from Chief Minister (primarily responsible); previous judgment accepted distinction.

holdings.text: The Chief Minister was not disqualified from hearing the objections as the same infirmity as the Secretary did not attach to him.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional rules (Art. 166) and government business rules distinguish Minister (primarily responsible) from Secretary (head of department); estoppel as not raised earlier.

holdings.text: The Chief Minister did not disqualify himself by acts or speeches showing bias.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof of personal bias; scheme initiated by General Manager not CM; newspaper speeches not proved by affidavit or admission, mere extracts insufficient evidence.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority did not strictly comply with Rule 11 requiring due notice before rendering permits ineffective.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 11 read with s.68F(2) requires notice before order; here order made first then communicated same day, only one day to comply not 'due' or reasonable notice.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly refused to exercise jurisdiction under Art. 226 despite the procedural defect due to supervening circumstances and lack of practical utility.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants withdrew vehicles, Corporation operating; quashing would be empty formality causing confusion without benefit.
